journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Clinical experience with computer navigation in revision total hip arthroplasty

article-meta.aff: 1MINTOS – Medical Imaging and Navigation in Trauma and Orthopaedic Surgery, BG Trauma Center Ludwigshafen at Heidelberg University Hospital, Ludwigshafen, Germany
2Surgery, Institute for Surgical Technology and Biomechanics, University of Bern, Bern, Switzerland

author-notes.corresp: Jochen Franke, MINTOS – Medical Imaging and Navigation in Trauma and Orthopaedic Surgery, BG Trauma Center Ludwigshafen at Heidelberg University Hospital, Ludwig-Guttmann-Straße 13, D-67071 Ludwigshafen, Germany. Email: jochen.franke@bgu-ludwigshafen.de

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on orthopaedic navigation technology and biomechanical evaluation for total hip replacement

abstract.p: The biomechanically and anatomically correct placement of hip prostheses components is the main challenge in revision hip arthroplasty. The orientation of the cup and stem with the restoration of leg length, offset and hip centre is hampered by the defect situations frequently present. In primary hip arthroplasty, it has been demonstrated that the components can be accurately positioned using computer-navigated procedures. However, such procedures could also be of considerable benefit in revision hip arthroplasty. Systems that not only detect anatomical landmarks using pointers but also use image data for referencing may provide a possible solution for the defect situation. Literature about navigation in revision arthroplasty is very rare. This article comprises general considerations on this subject and presents our experience and possible clinical applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Accurate placement of the components in hip arthroplasty affects both the short-term and long-term results. This is equally true for both primary and revision arthroplasty. Anchorage of the prostheses, correct implantation technique and tribology are all important considerations but the correct positioning of the components is one of the essential factors affecting the life and function of the prosthesis. During implantation, in particular, the conventional orientation techniques used for the acetabular component vary greatly.1,2 In recent years, computer-assisted procedures have been developed with the aim of improving the precision of surgical interventions.3–5

Biomechanically inadequate positioning of the implants leads almost inevitably to complications. In the short term, this gives rise to a higher dislocation rate, a limited range of motion due to bony or implant-related impingement and leg length discrepancies. In the long run, unphysiological load can lead to premature wear and aseptic loosening of the prosthesis.6,7 Whereas in large studies, the dislocation rate in primary arthroplasty is about 1%–2%, in revision total hip arthroplasty (THA), it is reported in 5%–27% of all cases.8–11 The main reasons for these high dislocation rates are the difficulties in the positioning and the orientation of the components. In revision arthroplasty, soft tissue reconstruction plays a role as well. Restoration of the centre of rotation of the hip, offset and leg length are important factors for the positioning of the implant. Areas of bone loss further complicate the treatment considerably, and there are a lot of different options to solve this challenging problem. Loss of bone stock at the acetabulum and the proximal femur can be treated using bone autografts, allografts, bone graft subtitutes12–14 or cemented implants.15,16 In particular, reconstruction of acetabular defects can be managed with screw-fixated implants,17 jumbo cups,16,18 metal augments and shells,16,17 acetabular cages17 or custom implants.19 In every case, reconstruction of the defect situation is the prerequisite for a proper implantation of the new components.

Cup orientation with regard to anteversion and inclination as well as the restoration of the physiological hip centre is of key importance to correct implantation (Figure 1). By correlating the complication rates in primary arthroplasty with the orientation of the implanted acetabular cup, various authors have established the ‘so-called’ safe zones for cup placement. Cups implanted in this range of tolerance tend to subluxate and dislocate significantly less frequently.20–23

caption.p: Dislocation with obvious steep inclination of the acetabular cup.

sec.p: This finding equally applies to revision arthroplasty. Therefore, by setting the correct position of the cup and stem, the aim of hip navigation is to lower the complication rate in the early phase and to improve the long-term results.

Hip replacements are conventionally planned using templates and X-rays in a two-dimensional (2D) plane. Although this allows the inclination and size of the prosthesis to be estimated relatively well, the correct anteversion cannot be determined.24 In revision arthroplasty, in particular, correct restoration of the centre of rotation of the prosthesis is a planning and surgical challenge that not only requires considerable three-dimensional (3D) imaging facilities but also requires advanced knowledge of the various implant options and surgical variants.19

It is difficult to calculate the correct position of the patient on the operating table as certain anatomical conditions, for example, hip flexion contracture on the contralateral side or hyperlordosis, could lead to tilting or distortion of the pelvis.25 Moreover, in the case of revision, the usual anatomical orientation points may be absent.

Conventional mechanical orientation aids that orientate themselves in space or an orientation of the pelvis believed to be correct by the surgeon and not orientated under anatomical conditions are often not reliable enough. In the case of anteversion, in particular, this cannot be assessed accurately enough intra-operatively.20,26–28 The relative movement of the pelvis during the operation makes matters more difficult. Technically more elaborate mechanical instruments developed by Doyle et al.,29 which aimed to make a more ‘anatomy-orientated’ orientation possible, have not been successful.

sec.title: Computer navigation in revision arthroplasty
sec.p: Literature about navigation in revision arthroplasty is very rare. Reported works focus on computer-assisted femoral bone cement removal in revision arthroplasty,30–32 but no clinical trials about navigation in revision THA are published yet. This article comprises general considerations on this subject and presents our experience and possible clinical applications.

In the case of primary arthroplasty, computer-assisted implant positioning has been used for more than 15 years. These systems include computed tomography (CT)–based, fluoroscopy-based and imageless systems with intra-operative definition of the patient’s anatomy (kinematic analysis, landmark definition).

Although CT-based navigation can be used successfully in many clinical cases,33,34 the disadvantages limit routine use in the clinical situation. Both pre-operative planning and the intra-operative registration of the CT data set with the patient’s anatomy, so-called matching, involve a clear learning curve and are error-prone. In revision arthroplasty, it is even more difficult to segment the data set obtained from the CT scan because of the implants already in place and the associated artefacts. Nevertheless, a clear advantage is that the defect situation can be accurately visualised in three dimensions, which greatly facilitates pre-operative planning.

As stated earlier, in revision arthroplasty, bone defects can seriously hamper orientation using anatomical landmarks. This also applies to the kinematic analysis of the baseline situation. This places limitations on imageless navigation systems. Then, the use of systems with the additional facility of being able to incorporate data from registered image intensifiers is helpful in defining the exact position of the acetabular component.

One example of the use of computer-assisted methods in revision arthroplasty is the implantation of individual endoprostheses. In the case of large acetabular defects, it can be useful to create a model of the pelvis from a CT data set. Before the procedure, at least three marker screws are inserted into the pelvis under local anaesthetics to make intra-operative registration easier and to achieve better accuracy. In accordance to the patient-specific anatomic model, an individualised prosthesis can then be manufactured. The anchoring of the prosthesis is planned and simulated in the model. Corresponding anchorage holes are planned on the individualised prosthesis for transiliosacral screw placement. The transiliosacral screws are then inserted intra-operatively under computer-assisted guidance (Figure 2(a) to (d)).

caption.p: (a) Large supra-acetabular defect after deep infection following revision arthroplasty. (b) Pelvic 3D model from the CT data set of the patient with individual prosthesis (rapid prototyping). (c) Intra-operative representation of the transiliosacral screws for proximal anchoring of the individual prosthesis. (d) Post-operative X-ray, the marker screws can be seen on the iliac crest.

sec.title: Navigation with kinematic and landmark-based registration
sec.p: Information on the patient’s individualised anatomy as well as the pre-operative and intra-operative kinematics are obtained during the procedure. Anatomical landmarks are ascertained during the operation using a navigated pointer, and based on their geometrical configuration, a virtual model of the patient’s anatomy is created.

Imageless navigation systems based on anatomical landmarks and kinematic analyses are being increasingly used in primary arthroplasty but are only used to a limited extent in revision arthroplasty. In general, it is no longer possible to digitise anatomical landmarks on the acetabulum, and the kinematic analysis of the hip joint with the generally loose implant still in place is not usable.

sec.title: Principle of navigation with the registered image intensifier
sec.p: The image data coordinate system can be automatically converted into the coordinate system of the patient’s anatomy. For this, the positions of both coordinate systems must be known when recording the image data. As a reference marker has to be attached to the patient to do this, automatic registration can only be done intra-operatively (Figure 3). In principle, all image sources that are available intra-operatively can be used. Because of the physical properties, ultrasound is of secondary importance in skeletal surgery. Large devices such as CT or even magnetic resonance tomography units are only available intra-operatively at a few centres.

caption.p: Principle of intra-operative automatic registration with a navigated X-ray image intensifier.

sec.p: The most valuable device for intra-operative imaging is the X-ray image intensifier (XRII). The camera captures the patient’s position through the position of the reference markers and at the same time the position of the image source. Light-emitting diodes (LEDs) are attached to the image intensifier to make this possible. The images of each conventional C-arm are distorted in a barrel and cushion-shaped manner. The distortion is different in each C-arm model and in each individual C-arm position. The algorithm for correcting images is therefore calibrated for each possible position of the C-arm navigated. The image intensifier is calibrated once with a phantom (extrinsic calibration) or in each individual intensified image intra-operatively. Images are taken in the standard projections relevant to the procedure with a navigated, calibrated C-arm. Several fluoroscopy images may be available simultaneously as optical information on the screen in a type of virtual fluoroscopy.

sec.title: Referencing
sec.p: During the surgical procedure, there are always relative movements between the camera, instruments and the patient. Therefore, before registration, a reference marker that follows the patient’s movements must be attached to the bone that will be operated on. It is important that the markers are fixed in a rigid and stable manner for this. The markers record all movements of the bone due to manipulation by the surgeon. The navigation is therefore independent of the patient’s movements on the operating table.

sec.title: An example for cup navigation in revision arthroplasty
sec.p: Similar to primary THA, in revision arthroplasty, the reference plane for cup placement is the anterior pelvic plane (APP) described by Cunningham35 in 1922. The APP is defined by four anatomical landmarks: the anterior superior iliac spines and the pubic tubercles.35 In patients without hip joint arthrosis and physiological conditions affecting the spine, this plane is approximately parallel to the frontal plane both standing and lying down36 (Figure 4).

caption.p: Landmarks for defining the anterior pelvic plane.

sec.p: We report on presents a CT-free navigation system, which uses a hybrid strategy to acquire the pelvic landmarks that are useful for revision surgery. Here, the methods of landmark-based navigation are combined with the registration of non-directly accessible landmarks using fluoroscopy images in two planes. It is also possible to directly visualise the position of the implant in the virtual navigated X-ray image.

In principle, each landmark can be determined with the pointer or the navigated image intensifier.5 Bony landmarks can be defined in these registered fluoroscopy images, which are arranged in 3D space with geometric precision by the calibrated rectification algorithm. In the surgical technique, in the supine position, the necessary landmarks for defining the APP are determined by percutaneous detection of the anterior superior iliac spines with a referenced pointer and ascertaining the geometrical centre of the pubic tubercles with the image converter (Figure 5).

caption.p: Combination from direct digitisation of the landmarks on the patient with landmark definition from registered fluoroscopy images.

sec.p: From the anatomically defined points and the points defined in the navigated fluoroscopy images, the navigation system calculates the APP and displays on the screen, in ‘real time’, the position, nature and size of the navigated instrument as well as the angle of inclination and anteversion (Figure 6).

caption.p: Intra-operative visualisation of the cup position in relation to the anterior pelvic plane in the registered fluoroscopy images.

sec.title: Surgical procedure
sec.p: Compared to the conventional procedure, no additional pre-operative steps are needed to incorporate navigation with intra-operative registration in the operation. The strategy for implanting the revision cup should, of course, be decided at the pre-operative planning stage. The hip joint is prepared in the usual way. After the primary implant has been removed and the acetabulum has been debrided, a reference marker is fixed firmly to the iliac crest.

In the first part of the registration of the APP, in supine position, the two anterior superior iliac spines are digitised with the referenced pointer. The third point for defining the APP is determined from halving the line between the pubic tubercles. The pubic tubercles can be registered more accurately and precisely with the C-arm. On registering with the referenced image converter, two oblique approximately 60° diverging planes are registered in the ‘inlet’ and ‘outlet’ projection in order to visualise the geometric centre of both tubercles (Figure 7). In lateral decubitus position, the anterior superior iliac spine that is no longer accessible after sterile drapes have been applied can also be digitised with the referenced fluoroscopy.

caption.p: Inlet and outlet projection technique for defining the ‘pubic point’ in registered fluoroscopy images.

sec.p: Other registered fluoroscopy images can also be incorporated. The information from an individual anterior–posterior (a.p.) view centred on the hip joint can be very helpful. Oblique projections (ala and obturator projection) can also be taken. With these projections, the restoration of the hip centre, the depth of cup placement and the remaining bony structures can be visualised in two dimensions. Another advantage of fluoroscopy-based navigation is the intra-operative updating of the images. For example, the position of the cup in relation to an implanted acetabular reinforcement ring can be visualised (Figure 8).

caption.p: Visualisation of cup placement in revision arthroplasty. The fluoroscopy image was updated after implantation of the acetabular reinforcement ring; the position of the cup (PE inlay) in relation to the anterior pelvic plane is indicated.

sec.title: Summary and outlook
sec.p: The system presented combines the widely used fluoroscopy with computer navigation. A hybrid strategy is pursued to digitise the landmarks which, on the one hand, make it possible to carry out rapid percutaneous pointer-based digitisation of surface landmarks and, on the other, the non-invasive 3D reconstruction of deep landmarks in registered intensified images.

Systems are currently available, which also support the navigation of the stem or a type of ‘express navigation’, providing only offset and leg length.37,38 These may lead to an additional potential benefit for revision arthroplasty.

The incorporation of 2D/3D reconstruction may facilitate new possibilities in the future. With this procedure, a patient-specific virtual 3D model of the pelvis can already be generated from a simple 2D a.p. pelvic X-ray39 (Figure 9). With the 2D/3D reconstruction method, CT for measuring cup orientation (inclination/anteversion) can now be replaced.40 Further applications will follow. In the meantime, however, a lot of development work still needs to be done.

caption.p: Individual 3D model of the pelvis created by 2D/3D reconstruction with landmarks of the anterior pelvic plane marked by way of example.

sec.p: Computer navigation will only be used successfully in revision arthroplasty once sufficient experience has been acquired in primary arthroplasty. Nowadays, risk reduction and the quality of surgical procedures are of paramount importance. The potential benefit of navigation in revision arthroplasty may be considerable and obvious, but in view of the current limitations, the limited availability of the systems and the limited integration of revision implants, little clinical experience has been gained so far.
